content: The Act may be cited as the "Home-Assembled Firearms Restriction Act of 2015" and includes a ban on do-it-yourself assault weapons. The "Home-Assembled Firearms Restriction Act of 2015" bans certain hazardous products including firearm receiver castings, assault weapon parts kits, and machinegun parts kits. These products are considered banned hazardous products under the Consumer Product Safety Act. Enforcement of this ban falls under section 19 of the Consumer Product Safety Act. The Consumer Product Safety Commission consults with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives for effective enforcement strategies under section 19 of the Consumer Product Safety Act. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION OF ADVERTISING DO-IT-YOURSELF ASSAULT WEAPONS. It is illegal to advertise for the sale of firearm receiver castings, assault weapon parts kits, and machinegun parts kits that can be completed by the consumer to function as firearms. Enforcement is overseen by the Federal Trade Commission. The Federal Trade Commission enforces rules prohibiting the sale of firearm receiver castings, assault weapon parts kits, and machinegun parts kits that can be assembled by consumers. This enforcement is carried out under the same authority as the Federal Trade Commission Act, without limiting the Commission's authority under other laws. The curr_chunk is a section titled "SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS." The curr_chunk defines terms related to firearms, including "assault weapon parts kit," "machinegun parts kit," and "semiautomatic assault weapon." These terms are crucial for understanding the regulations outlined in the Act. The curr_chunk defines terms related to firearms, including the capacity for detachable ammunition magazines and specific features for classification. It also clarifies terms such as "machinegun," "semiautomatic pistol," "semiautomatic rifle," and "semiautomatic shotgun." A semiautomatic pistol has special features including an external ammunition magazine, a threaded barrel for attachments, a shroud for barrel protection, a weight of 50 ounces or more when unloaded, and being a semiautomatic version of an automatic firearm. SEC. 5. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not limit states from enacting stricter gun laws or bans on certain firearm parts.
